newsitem.title: USA: US West Coast crudes up sharply, discount to fall.
newsitem.headline: US West Coast crudes up sharply, discount to fall.

text.p: U.S. West Coast crudes rose sharply Thursday, boosted by a rally in West Coast/Cushing (WTI) prices, but buyers said the discount for Alaska grade will widen under pressure from incoming foreign barrels.
The physical market for WTI tracked a rally in benchmark U.S. crudes, which gained support on a rally in unleaded gasoline futures.
Benchmark U.S. crudes rose 70 cents to $20.30-40 late Thursday, sparked by the 1.58-cent rise in NYMEX gasoline.

Traders said Atlantic Richfield Co. was close to buying two 400,000 barrel cargoes of Mesa crude, a Venezuelan lookalike to Alaska North Slope (gravity 30 degrees), for June delivery to West Coast refiners.
Another major buyer, Texaco, was well supplied for June after taking two to three cargoes of Oriente, traders said.
The high volume of imports could undermine the value of ANS, last sold at minus $1.32 a barrel on May 5.
Refiners saw offers as high as $1.15 a barrel, and as low as the $1.30-40 a barrel range.
"I would expect a deal to get done at $1.50 (under WTI)," a buyer said.
Outright ANS prices rose 75 cents a barrel to $18.93/19.13, $1 a barrel higher than Line 63, a similar grade, and $4.12 overCalifornia heavy grades.
The Department of Energy had not found a buyer for light crude leftover for June/July delivery from the Elk Hills Naval Petroleum Reserve.
Ample foreign crudes dampened demand for the crude, which saw only 11,025 of 16,100 barrels-per-day (bpd) purchased in last week's auction.
Kern River crude was pegged $14.01/14.11 a barrel.
Wilmington and Line 63 markets remained idle.
